question: During a junior golf match, your ball lands in a deep tyre mark. You think it might be considered 'ground under repair,' but you're not totally sure of the rule.*

choices.text: Play two balls, one from the tyre mark and another from where you would normally expect to get relief then clarify the rules in the pro shop at the end of the round.
Take a risk and just drop the ball clear of the damaged ground.
Ask your playing partners to vote on whether you should move the ball or play it as it lies.
You are allowed to play two balls, but you must tell someone and also discuss which ball you would prefer to be counted.

explanation: When you're unsure about a golf rule, you can play a second ball to keep the game fair. First, tell your playing partners what you're doing. Choose which ball you'd like to count, just in case the rules allow it. After the hole, get the right rule checked to see which ball's play was correct. This keeps the game honest and lets you learn the rules as you play.
